item.title: Blackstone invests $100M in elite marketing tech firm
item.description: Applecart has a leading place in an emerging but discreet cohort of companies and organizations aimed at reaching key figures in industry and government.

item.title: Politico announces layoffs, new product
item.description: The publication will cut about 3% of its 750-strong global staff.

item.title: Undersecretary Sarah Rogers on free speech, Europe’s tech crackdown, and the internet she misses
item.description: The State Department’s undersecretary for public diplomacy joins Mixed Signals for a wide-ranging conversation about free speech, tech regulation, and why she’s been rattling the patience of some European governments.

item.title: Die Welt editor departed amid internal inquiry
item.description: The editor of Germany’s Die Welt had been the subject of internal scrutiny in recent days by the newspaper’s parent company.

item.title: Streaming giants push filmmakers to adapt to ‘double screening’
item.description: Viewers are increasingly watching films and TV while also looking at their smartphones.

item.title: Freakonomics’ Stephen Dubner on why long-form podcasting isn’t dead yet
item.description: Stephen Dubner has spent 20 years proving that things aren’t what they seem—and now he’s not so sure that’s always true.

item.title: “We’re not trying to recreate social media”: How Minnesota’s Star Tribune navigates a local crisis
item.description: The publication tries to offer a sober alternative to a social media swarm as a deadly shooting deepens the crisis in Minneapolis.

item.title: Rumors of staffing cuts spook Washington Post newsroom
item.description: Feared potential targets for cuts include the sports and international desks.

item.title: Washington Post’s White House team tries to avert layoffs in letter to Bezos
item.description: The effort from the Post’s White House reporters comes as staffers are scrambling to preserve their jobs ahead of impending layoffs.

item.title: The exec behind Canada’s surprise hit ‘Heated Rivalry’ on the secret to its success
item.description: Sean Cohan gets into the Canadian-ness of it all on the “Mixed Signals” podcast.

item.title: It’s Rupe vs. the Quiff! In California’s new tabloid war, everybody wins
item.description: The California Post is betting its buzzy launch on a war with Gov. Gavin Newsom.

item.title: Podcast brand Kaleidoscope staffs up
item.description: The company is filling out its executive ranks as it hopes to break further into video.

item.title: Washington Post to make ‘significant’ cuts
item.description: The paper is beginning “a broad strategic reset with a significant staff reduction,” Washington Post executive editor Matt Murray said.

item.title: Post cuts ripple through US journalism industry
item.description: But people who’ve spoken to owner Jeff Bezos say there’s no sign he’s looking to sell.

item.title: How McDonald’s embraced its Donald Trump drive-thru moment
item.description: Former CMO Tariq Hassan on why brands shouldn’t run away from news, politics and controversy.

item.title: Washington Post CEO resigns, leaving no clear strategy
item.description: Will Lewis and Jeff Bezos presided over a sharp decline at the definitive Washington newspaper.

item.title: New emails show how Epstein used the media to rehab his reputation
item.description: Most of the revelations in the files have not revealed journalistic sins, but have highlighted uncomfortably close relationships.

item.title: Washington Post suffers marketing mishap with new slogan
item.description: The paper had prepared a new brand campaign, with a new tagline meant to convey its connection to America: “We The People.”
